Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: The Long Term Relationship Between Political Authority And Economic Organization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
A major concern of social science research has been to identify the mechanisms underlying the development of socially complex societies and the ways in which larger towns and cities exert centripetal forces that draw together and integrate the populations of these societies. Only archaeology can trace the earliest parts of this development, during which the patterns built on later were established. Systematic study of early complex societies has shown considerable variability in the social, environmental, and economic conditions that foster their development, and comparisons of archaeological cases reveal patterns in this variability that provide insight into how different developmental forces can combine and complement each other. This project will focus especially on the relationship between political authority and the organization of systems for providing a population with the utilitarian goods of daily life. The connections between early rulers and these basic economic systems are poorly known. Researchers ask whether, how, and to what extent controlling, managing, or profiting from the production and distribution of basic goods contributed to the ability of early rulers to project their political authority. The different forms that this relationship could take might set the stage for political entities founded on different core principles and lead to greater or lesser long-term political stability. Greater understanding of the basic factors that encourage economic development and political stability in large-scale societies makes a clear contribution in a world composed of such societies, with varied organizational patterns and histories and and with different degrees of success in achieving political stability and in providing for the economic needs of their populations.

This project will assess the degree to which changes in distribution networks of basic goods correspond with the centralization and decentralization of political units. Under the supervision of Dr. Robert D. Drennan, the doctoral candidate, Camilla Kelsoe, will carry out a geochemical analysis of a sample of utilitarian pottery sherds recovered by previous research from two Neolithic walled towns in the Jianghan Plain of south-central China. Patterns in the compositional variability of these pottery sherds will be examined to delineate pottery distribution networks through the late Neolithic period (3300-2000 BCE). One of these two towns, Xiaocheng, developed and became increasingly centralized through this period, while the population of the other, Taojiahu, became less centralized. These alternative trajectories present an ideal case in which to systematically assess the relationship between centralized political authority and economic development. In addition to its substantive results, the project will provide essential research training for the doctoral candidate and foster closer academic collaboration between the University of Pittsburgh and several institutions in China: Wuhan University, the Hubei Province Institute of Archaeology, the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and Central South University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of complex economic systems is seen as playing a central role in the emergence of hierarchically-organized societies. However there is little systematic understanding of how these two spheres are connected. Under the supervision of Dr. Robert D. Drennan, Camilla Kelsoe conducted a geochemical study of domestic pottery from the northern Jianghan Plain in Hubei Province to trace how patterns in the circulation of these vessels changed with the growth and decline of two large walled towns in the region. The investigation assessed the role that control over access to basic goods played in the development of political power in one complex society of the past. It thus helps us to understand more generally the ways in which politics, economy, and urban growth connect in the large-scale complex societies in which most of humanity lives in today.

 The study of material culture offers an important avenue for tracing economic interactions in the past. In particular, domestic pottery, used for cooking, serving, and storing food, can be used to investigate patterns of exchange among ancient groups due to its durability and to the fact that pottery was used by the majority of these populations on a daily basis. By characterizing the elemental and mineralogical composition of pottery sherds, it is possible to reconstruct where ancient pottery vessels were produced and networks through which they were exchanged.

 This project examined the compositional signatures of 1,150 pottery sherds collected in and around two Neolithic walled towns in southern China to see how access to and consumption of a basic, domestic good changed with demographic centralization and decentralization at these settlements. One of these towns, Taojiahu, was highly centralized and densely populated in the Qujialing period (3100–2500 BCE) but became smaller and more dispersed in the following Shijiahe period (2500–2000 BCE). By contrast, the second town, Xiaocheng, grew slowly and steadily in size and occupational density until the end of the third millennium BCE.

Analysis of the pottery recovered at Taojiahu, Xiaocheng, and their environs, has revealed that during the Qujialing period a large portion of pottery used in households throughout the region was circulated through large-scale regional exchange networks. By the Shijiahe period, more pottery was instead being produced and circulated through local networks. Neither period shows evidence that access to pottery exchange networks was constrained by social or political factors.

A key difference in the economic organization of Taojiahu and Xiaocheng is seen in the ways households in each town procured their pottery. At Taojiahu, consumers acquired relatively small proportions of pottery from a large number of producers; at Xiaocheng, consumers acquired a large proportion of their pottery from a restricted set of producers. These procurement patterns appear to have developed independently of absolute population size, as demographic growth at Xiaocheng resulted in increasing reliance on a fewer pottery providers, while the opposite was true at Taojiahu. Instead, these patterns may reflect variations in social network construction, with Xiaocheng households focused on developing a few, deep relationships with other groups, while Taojiahu households aimed to cultivate many, shallow relationships.

Demographic growth and the development of quasi-urban communities is correlated with two disparate economic trends in the late Neolithic. At Taojiahu, population growth corresponded with the expansion of regional exchange networks, while at Xiaocheng it occurred alongside the localization of exchange networks. These results also suggest that the development of economic and social networks that emphasized the strength of connections over their breadth enabled the long-term, stable integration of populations.

 As doctoral dissertation research, this project had broader outcomes as well. It provided essential training for the doctoral candidate in implementing and carrying out research of her own design. It also offered methodological training opportunities for students at Wuhan University (Hubei Province, China) and the University of Pittsburgh.
